Tel.: +1 505 277 0477; fax: +1 505 277 1024. We have studied the kinetics of methanol steam reforming on a commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in a packed bed reactor. The objective of this work was to assess the impact of deviations from isothermality in packed bed reactors on the rates of methanol steam reforming. Preliminary experiments with catalyst dilution showed higher apparent rate constants as the catalyst was diluted, implying heat transfer limitations in the bed. We therefore varied the reactor diameter from 4.1 mm down to 1 mm in order to improve heat transfer. The smaller diameter reactor showed higher apparent catalyst activity. This increased reactivity could be explained using a 2D pseudo-homogeneous reactor model. The heat transfer limitations result in a temperature gradient of up to 40 K in the 4.1 mm reactor. Even the 1 mm reactor suffers from temperature variations of up to 22 K. Since packed bed reactors are most commonly used for the production of H2 via steam reforming, it is important to recognize the role of these heat transfer limitations. Transport limitations can lead to falsified kinetics and lowered catalyst productivity. Superscript 0 stagnant ( R e = 0 ) 1 Introduction Compact fuel cell systems operating with hydrocarbon fuels possess high volumetric and gravimetric energy density and could outperform batteries in low-power, portable electronics [1]. The challenge is to develop efficient microreformers for converting the chemical fuel into H2 which can be fed to a proton exchange membrane fuel cell to produce electricity. Among the fuels considered, methanol is an attractive candidate since it is sulfur free, and most importantly, can be reformed at low temperatures ( 200 – 250 ° C) [2]. The low reforming temperature results in low CO concentration (1.5%) in the product gases. This makes it possible, with elevated-temperature ( 180 ° C) PEM fuel cells, to feed the reformate directly to the fuel cell without subsequent CO clean up. Fuel cell membranes made of polybenzimidazole (PBI) polymer allow high temperature operation of up to 200 ° C and performance is not affected by CO concentrations up to 3% [3]. For methanol steam reforming (MSR) at low temperatures, we have to operate with low gas velocity in order to achieve high conversions. The low gas velocity dramatically lowers the effective thermal conductivity of the catalyst bed [4]. Furthermore, the low ratio of reactor to catalyst particle diameter, and the low gas velocity tends to introduce a large heat transfer resistance between the wall and the catalyst particles [5]. It is well known that the void fraction at the wall is larger than in the center of the bed, and there are only limited number of contact points between the catalyst particles and the reactor wall. Hence the major heat transfer resistance between the wall and catalyst particles is due to the gas film. Under these conditions, increasing the solid thermal conductivity has only a modest impact in improving overall heat transfer. For an endothermic reaction such as MSR, temperature gradients in the packed bed lead to lowered catalyst activity and could also lead to falsified kinetics. Perry et al. [6] showed that microwave heating of a packed bed methanol reformer could help overcome the adverse temperature gradients in a packed bed. Tests for transport limitations generally involve the assessment of intraparticle and interphase gradients, by use of the Koros Nowak criterion [7] or the Weisz–Prater criterion [8]. Experimentally, this involves reducing the particle diameter, increasing superficial gas velocity or reducing the number of active sites per unit volume of catalyst so as to remain free of transport limitations. However, interparticle transport effects within the reactor occurring both radially and axially are particularly difficult to evaluate and control. If neglected, radial temperature gradients can lead to reaction rates several thousand-fold greater (for an exothermic reaction) at the axis than at the wall [9]. Mears [5] developed a criterion for evaluating the importance of radial heat transport in a reactor. The criterion accounts for the heat transfer resistance at the wall which cannot be neglected at d t / d p < 100 [9]. The vast majority of studies on MSR have been done using packed bed reactors of diameters ≥ 4 mm i.d. where d t / d p < 25 , e.g. [10–14]. The importance of heat transfer from the wall, particularly at low gas velocities is not well appreciated and is often neglected. There are no reported experimental measurements of the impact of heat transfer on the MSR reaction, or recommendations for reactor dimensions that would overcome transport limitations. In this work, we have performed an experimental study of the rate of MSR under conditions where we attempt to minimize the effect of transport limitations. The work was complemented by reactor modeling using a 2D pseudo-homogeneous model that allows us to calculate temperature profiles and to assess their impact on catalyst reactivity. The excellent agreement between the experimental data and the reactor model confirms our initial hypothesis that methanol steam reforming can be subject to severe heat transfer limitations in packed bed reactors. 2 Experimental Measurements of the steam reforming of methanol were performed in tubular packed bed reactors. The reactor consisted of a quartz tube positioned in an aluminum block heated by two cartridge-heaters. The space between the quartz tube and the aluminum block was filled with sand for better heat transfer. The inner diameters of the quartz tubes used in the experiments were 4.1, 1.75 and 1 mm. The temperature of the aluminum block was controlled by a temperature controller. The temperature of the reactor outer surface was measured and was equal to that of the aluminum block. The inlet and outlet temperatures of the reactor were also monitored. The reactor effluent stream passed through a gas-sampling valve, then through a condenser to trap unreacted water and methanol before reaching a digital mass flow meter which allowed for total product dry gas flow to be monitored. The effluent of the reactor was analyzed using a Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a Porapak Q column and a TCD detector, using helium as the carrier gas. The analysis of the gas phase species CO2, CO and CH3OH along with a carbon balance allowed the methanol conversion and CO2 selectivity to be calculated. The GC was programmed to sample reactor product gases at 20 min intervals around the clock. The entire system was automated by Labview software and appropriate data acquisition hardware. Material balance was done as follows: using the methanol conversion and CO2 selectivity and the reaction network stoichiometry, the total theoretical dry gas flow rate was calculated and compared to the reading of the mass flow meter. The error was less than 10% in all experiments. A commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst from BASF (F13456) was used in all the experiments. The catalyst was crushed and sieved to 100–250 μ m particle size. The same particle size was used for the different reactor sizes. d t / d p was within the acceptable range for a packed bed. A different aliquot from the crushed catalyst was used for each experiment. The CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 was used in its as-received, calcined state. The pressure drop across the catalyst bed was measured after packing each reactor prior to catalyst testing. The pressure regulator of an air cylinder was adjusted to flow 200 sccm of air at room temperature in an empty tube of the same size as the reactor, then the reactor was connected and the pressure regulator was adjusted again to get the same 200 sccm of air. The pressure drop over the catalyst bed was reported as the difference between the two pressure readings. The reactor was heated to the reaction temperature of 230 ° C under helium flow of 4 sccm at 15 ° C/min. The helium was left to flow for an hour after the temperature reached 230 ° C before the water methanol mixture was introduced to the reactor. A mixture of 1.1:1 molar water/methanol was pumped using an injection pump (Cole Parmer 74900) at 0.2 ml/h to an in-house built vaporizer operating at 130 ° C. The vaporizer was optimized to get a stable flow rate and minimize fluctuations in the water–methanol molar ratio [15]. After starting the methanol/water flow, 15–30 min were allowed for catalyst reduction. Kinetic data point collection was done by changing the flow rate of the liquid water/methanol mixture from low to high flow rate (high to low W/F). Since catalyst activity decayed with time on stream, all data points reported here were collected during the first 3 h period after starting the methanol/water flow, unless otherwise mentioned. Tests showed that the extent of deactivation during this initial period was 5–10% and will not affect the conclusions of this paper. 3 Results 3.1 Effect of catalyst dilution and reactor diameter on the apparent catalyst activity In order to check whether the 4.1 mm i.d. packed bed reactor was heat transfer limited, two experiments were conducted. In the first experiment, 200 mg catalyst was packed in the reactor, while for the second experiment 200 mg catalyst were mixed with 175 mg α-Al2O3 of the same particle size (tests showed that α-Al2O3 does not catalyze this reaction). The dilution with Al2O3 increased the bed length which in turn increased the bed external surface area available for heat transfer and also reduced the reaction rate per unit bed volume. It can be seen from the results in Fig. 1 that the diluted bed showed a higher apparent catalyst activity than the undiluted bed. We infer that the undiluted reactor might be subject to heat transfer limitations which were overcome, in part, when the catalyst is diluted. The interparticle temperature gradients can be minimized by dilution of the catalyst with an inert material, and also by dilution of the reactants with a diluent gas or by decreasing the reactor diameter. If one is interested in eliminating heat transfer gradients in a commercial reformer, dilution of the catalyst would increase the reactor volume and would therefore not be desirable. Reactant dilution is also not feasible in a commercial reformer due to the volume constraints. Therefore decreasing reactor diameter remains the best solution and the question that remains to be answered is what dimensions will be needed to eliminate temperature gradients and their adverse effect on reactivity. In order to answer this question, we measured the catalyst activity in three reactors having an i.d. of 4.1, 1.75 and 1 mm. The reactors were loaded with 100, 50 and 30 mg catalyst, and the pressure drop at 200 sccm of air at room temperature was 1, 3 and 14 psi, respectively. However, the pressure drop in the 1 mm reactor at the reaction conditions is only a few psi since the flow rate did not exceed 12 sccm. Therefore, the effect of pressure drop on reaction rate could be neglected. The same range of catalyst particle size (100–250 μ m) was used in the different size reactors. The catalyst activity measured in the 4.1 mm reactor is in close agreement to that reported in the literature [14,16]. However, the measured catalyst activity increased significantly with decreasing reactor diameter as shown in Fig. 2 . Also, from Fig. 2 we can infer that to achieve 90% methanol conversion for a given methanol flow rate, 25% more catalyst weight would be needed for the 1.75 mm i.d. reactor compared with the weight of the 1 mm i.d. reactor, and about 85% more for the 4.1 mm i.d. reactor. The disadvantage of using smaller diameter reactors is the higher pressure drop across the catalyst bed. The high pressure drop and the difficulties of catalyst packing prevented us from using reactors with diameter less than 1 mm. 3.2 Analysis of transport limitations Temperature and concentration gradients can exist in three domains [9]: • Intraparticle: gradients within individual catalyst particles. • Interphase: gradients between the external surface of the particles and the adjacent layer of fluid. • Interparticle: radial and axial gradients within the reactor as a whole. Mass and heat transfer limitations in these three domains were analyzed [15] and we concluded that these reactors were limited only by interparticle heat transfer. Therefore we focus on the interparticle heat transfer. 3.2.1 Interparticle heat transfer limitation criterion A criterion was derived by Mears [5] for the absence of significant temperature gradients between the catalyst particles. It assumes less than 5% difference in the reaction rate due to temperature difference between particles [5]. (1) | Δ H r | ℜ ′ R t 2 λ eff T w < 0.4 R ( T w / E a ) 1 + ( 4 λ eff / R t h w ) which can be rewritten in the form (2) | Δ H r | ℜ ′ R t 2 λ eff T w 2 R / E a 1 + 4 λ eff R t h w < 0.4 where R t is the reactor radius (m); T w the wall temperature (K); E a the activation energy (J/(g mol)); ℜ the measured reaction rate per unit particle volume (g mol/(m3 s)); ℜ ′ = ℜ ( ( 1 − ϕ ) / ( 1 + b ) ) the measured reaction rate per unit bed volume (g mol/(m3 s)); b the (dilution) (ml inert/ml catalyst); Δ H r the heat of reaction (J/(g mol K)); h w the heat transfer coefficient at the wall (W/(m2 K)); R the ideal gas constant = 8.314 J/(g mol K) and λ eff the effective thermal conductivity of the bed (W/(m K)). The second term in Eq. (2), 4 λ eff / R t h w , represents the heat transfer resistance at the wall, which cannot be neglected at small ratios of tube to particle diameters ( R t / R p ≈ 10 ) [5,9]. This heat transfer resistance at the wall term is on the order of 1 at very low flow rates. However, this term is often ignored by most experimentalists using the simplified version of this criterion, e.g. [17, p. 121]. Correlations for the bed effective thermal conductivity and the heat transfer coefficient at the wall are available in the literature, e.g.[4,18–21]. However, they are not very accurate at R e ≤ 20 , especially the correlations for h w . They can still be used to test the reactor for heat transfer limitations using the Mears criterion since the inaccuracy in h w will not significantly affect the results. Yagi and Kunii proposed the following formula for the bed effective thermal conductivity [4] (3) λ eff λ g = λ eff 0 λ g + ( α β ) ( P r R e ) where λ eff 0 is the effective conductivity with a stagnant gas ( R e = 0 ); λ g is the gas thermal conductivity and it was reported [19] α β = 0.05 for d t d p = 14 λ eff 0 / λ g can be calculated from [4] (4) λ eff 0 λ g = β 1 − ϕ ( λ g / λ s ) + ψ where β = 1 for spherical particles; ψ = 0.04 for ϕ = 0.4 ; λ s is the catalyst thermal conductivity. A correlation for the heat transfer coefficient at the wall at low Reynolds number ( R e ≤ 20 ) is given by [19] (5) h w d p λ g = h w 0 d p λ g + α w ( P r R e ) where h w 0 is the heat transfer coefficient at R e = 0 ; α w = mass velocity in the direction of heat transfer near the wall surface / mass velocity based on area of the empty tube in the direction of fluid flow For packed beds, Yagi and Kunii reported [19] (6) α w = 0.054 It can be seen from the above equations that the heat transfer coefficient at the wall at low Peclet number ( P e = R e P r ) will be equal to that of a stagnant gas. For packed beds Yagi and Kunii reported that the Nusselt number at the wall in a stagnant gas ( N w 0 = h w 0 d p / λ g ) ranged from 1.2–8 [19]. For the size of particles used in our experiments, a Nusselt number at the wall ( N w 0 ) of 1.2 is reasonable and will be used in our calculations. 3.2.2 Application of the radial heat transfer criterion to experimental data The experimental conversion data were fitted to a first-order kinetic model in methanol [22] and the derived first-order rate constant k 1 ′ was used to test the reactors using the criteria discussed above. Table 1 lists k 1 ′ and the calculated values of the different transport limitation criteria for the different reactor sizes. The calculation used the reaction rate at the beginning of the bed where the reaction rate is at its highest. The temperature drop in the bed was calculated using the following expression [5]. (7) T min = T w − 1 4 | Δ H r | ℜ ′ R t 2 λ eff 1 + 4 λ eff R t h w (8) Δ T = T w − T min Table 1 shows that the packed bed reactors suffer from large radial temperature gradients. The estimated Δ T (difference between the temperatures of the wall and catalyst bed) was about 65 K in the 4.1 mm i.d. reactor which significantly lowers the measured catalyst activity compared to that in the smaller diameter reactors. The effect of temperature gradients can be seen in the increased apparent catalyst activity, with lower Δ T , in the smaller diameter reactors. 3.3 2D pseudo-homogeneous model The software program Femlab 2.3a (Comsol Inc.) was used to develop a 2D pseudo-homogeneous model for the packed bed reactors used in this study. 3.3.1 Model description The methanol steam reforming reaction can be written in the form (9) A + B → C + 3 D where A ≡ CH 3 OH ; B ≡ H 2 O ; C ≡ CO 2 ; D ≡ H 2 . At the temperature and pressure under consideration the mixture can be treated as an ideal gas, therefore, the Stefan–Maxwell equations were used to calculate the mean effective binary diffusivity [23]. (10) D Am = 6.8 × 1 0 − 5 m 2 / s this value for the mean effective binary diffusivity ( D Am ) is weakly dependent on the methanol conversion and is almost constant along the reactor length. A comprehensive reaction network model that accounts for the all the reactants and products would significantly increase the computational requirements. Also, since we are mainly focusing on the impact of heat transfer effects on the measured methanol conversion, the type of the reaction rate law used will not change the conclusions of this work. Therefore, the MSR reaction rate law will be taken to be first order in methanol and zero order in water. Since the diffusion coefficient of methanol in the reaction mixture could be taken as constant, then we could simplify the reaction to (11) A → 3 D The reaction rate will be given by (12) − r A = k 1 C A ( 1 − ϕ ) Expressing C A in terms of methanol conversion, the reaction rate may be represented as (13) − r A = k 1 C A 0 ( 1 − X A ) 1 + ε X A P P 0 T 0 T ( 1 − ϕ ) where ε = δ y A 0 = 2 × ( 1 / 2.1 ) = 0.9524 (H2O/CH3OH molar ratio = 1.1 ). Pressure drop will be neglected in the model ( P ≈ P 0 ) to give (14) − r A = k 1 C A 0 ( 1 − X A ) 1 + ε X A T 0 T ( 1 − ϕ ) The first-order reaction constant k 1 is evaluated using the Arrhenius equation. (15) k 1 = A exp ⁡ − E a R T The volumetric flow rate change with conversion and temperature is accounted for in the gas velocity expression as follows (16) U = U 0 ( 1 + ε X A ) T T 0 Properties of the gas and catalyst bed are given below, the gas physical properties are taken as an average of the mixture over several methanol conversions between 0 and 1: ρ g = 0.5 kg/m3; C p = 2000 J/(kg K); λ g = 0.04 W/(m K); λ eff = 0.17 W/(m K); d p = 150 μ m; h w = 320 W/(m2 K); ρ bulk = 890 kg/m3. The boundary conditions for the energy and mass balance equations are as follows: at the reactor inlet: T = T 0 = 503 K; C A = C A 0 = 11.6 g mol/m3. At the reactor walls: q → ⋅ n → = h w ( T − T w ) ( T w = 503 K ) ; N → i ⋅ n → = 0 . At the reactor outlet: q → ⋅ n → = convective flux ; N → i ⋅ n → = convective flux . 3.3.2 Modeling results The 2D model uses a finite difference method with a stationary nonlinear solver and a weak solution form. Fig. 3 shows the results of the 2D pseudo-homogeneous model developed in Femlab. The model has only one adjustable parameter which is the pre-exponential factor A in the Arrhenius equation. A was fit to the experimental data obtained in the 4.1 mm i.d. packed bed reactor to get A = 22 × 1 0 9 s−1. This value was fixed and the dimensions of the reactor were adjusted to model the 1.75 and 1 mm i.d. reactors. We can see from Fig. 3 that the model results fit the experimental data very well. We attribute the difference between the model and the data at low W/F to deactivation of the catalyst since the experimental data were obtained by starting at a low flow rate and increasing the flow rate with time (moving from right to left along the curve). The same deviation at low W/F can also be seen in Fig. 2. Next, we compare the temperature drop in the different reactor diameters. The comparison was done at the same methanol conversion of 0.86. Figs. 4–6 show the temperature profiles in the 4.1, 1.75 and 1 mm i.d. reactors respectively. The temperature drop was 40 K in the 4.1 mm reactor, 27 K in the 1.75 mm reactor and 22 K in the 1 mm reactor. It can be seen that the temperature drop in the reactors is close to what we estimated using the Mears criterion (see Table 1). 3.4 Estimation of packed bed diameter for isothermal operation The reactor dimensions required to eliminate temperature gradients were estimated using: (1) Mears criterion for radial heat transfer (Eq. (2)). (2) 2D Femlab model. 3.4.1 Estimation using mears criterion In this calculation we used a reaction rate constant k 1 ′ = 0.04524 m3/(kg s) corresponding to the pre-exponential factor ( A = 22 × 1 0 9 s−1) obtained from the 2D model (Section 3.3.2). The reactor radius ( R t ) in Eq. (2) was then varied until the criterion was satisfied. The ratio of reactor to catalyst particle diameter was fixed to a value of 10 in order to avoid by-passing [23]. All the other parameters were calculated using the correlations described earlier in the paper. The reactor diameter estimated from this correlation was 250 μm which would require catalyst particles diameter of 25 μm. 3.4.2 Estimation using Femlab In this calculation we fixed the ratio of reactor to catalyst particle diameter to a value of 10. The pre-exponential factor was fixed to the same value of 22 × 1 0 9 s−1. h w was calculated from Eq. (5). The reactor diameter was then varied until Δ T ≤ 3 K. Fig. 7 shows the effect of reactor diameter on the apparent catalyst activity. A reactor diameter of 300 μ m was found to have a Δ T of 3 K. However, the temperature gradient in the 700 μ m reactor is 9 K, not much larger than in the 300 μ m. In turn, the effect of diameter from 700 μ m down to 300 μ m on apparent catalyst activity is not significant, especially at high methanol conversions. Also, at high conversions, axial dispersion could lower the methanol conversion if short catalyst bed is used. Fig. 8 shows the effect of bed length on the methanol conversion obtained using the 2D model for the 4.1 mm i.d. reactor. 4 Summary In order to achieve isothermal operation in packed bed reactors, we need to use very small diameter reactors and according to our results, the reactor i.d. should be close to 300 μ m. For this configuration, using the Ergun equation, we could predict a pressure drop of 100 atm at 48 sccm and 30 mg of catalyst. Although novel bed configurations could reduce this pressure drop [24,25], we see that a packed bed microreactor is not an attractive choice if we want to operate free of heat transfer limitations. The heat transfer limitation could be eliminated by coating a thin layer of the catalyst on the inner walls of the reactor, thus avoiding the pressure drop associated with packed bed microreactors. The temperature could be more easily controlled and the reactor will operate isothermally [26]. A comparison of wall-coated microreactors with packed bed reactors is currently under way in our lab. 5 Conclusions The activity of CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 for the steam reforming of methanol was measured in packed bed reactors of different sizes. The reactivity results showed that the reactors suffered from significant temperature gradients. This was confirmed by the analysis of heat transfer limitations using the Mears criterion [5] and a 2D pseudo-homogeneous model developed using Femlab. We estimated the smallest diameter required for a packed bed to achieve near isothermal operation to be 300 μ m. The modeling results were in agreement with the experiments and also in agreement with the predictions made using the Mears criterion. The 2D pseudo-homogeneous model confirmed the fact that the measured catalyst activities in different diameter reactors varied solely due to heat transfer effects. This study clearly shows that the majority of activity measurements for the steam reforming of methanol reaction reported in the literature could be influenced by temperature gradients within the reactor. The analysis presented here can be easily extended to other endothermic or exothermic reactions to check for heat transfer limitations [15]. coredata.dc:description: We have studied the kinetics of methanol steam reforming on a commercial CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst in a packed bed reactor. The objective of this work was to assess the impact of deviations from isothermality in packed bed reactors on the rates of methanol steam reforming. Preliminary experiments with catalyst dilution showed higher apparent rate constants as the catalyst was diluted, implying heat transfer limitations in the bed. We therefore varied the reactor diameter from 4.1 mm down to 1 mm in order to improve heat transfer. The smaller diameter reactor showed higher apparent catalyst activity. This increased reactivity could be explained using a 2D pseudo-homogeneous reactor model. The heat transfer limitations result in a temperature gradient of up to 40 K in the 4.1 mm reactor. Even the 1 mm reactor suffers from temperature variations of up to 22 K. Since packed bed reactors are most commonly used for the production of H2 via steam reforming, it is important to recognize the role of these heat transfer limitations. Transport limitations can lead to falsified kinetics and lowered catalyst productivity.
coredata.dc:title: Nonisothermality in packed bed reactors for steam reforming of methanol
